channel.title: Good 3D Engine
channel.description:
I'm currently working on an RPG, and I'm in need of a good 3D engine. The must have list:
[ul][li]Support C#.net.[/li] [li]OpenGL if possible[/li] [li]Basic physics.[/li][/ul]

item.title: Good 3D Engine
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Axiom is said to be somewhat dated / inactive. They chose to make a full port, so they always lag behind the real Ogre and they don’t support all features. If you can use native libraries (dlls), you might wanna use Mogre instead. A few classes are ported for efficiency, but it is mostly bindings only. Can be used from C# and the other .NET languages, and is usually relatively up to date as compared to the main Ogre version. Also, precissely because they are bindings, you have a much easier access to other ogre plugins. (Especifically, there are already a MogreNewt (Physics Library) and a MOIS (Input Library), plus some others).

About XNA and OpenGL, these are indeed much lower level. If you wanna learn the basics of 3D graphics, dealing with things such as transformation / projection matrices, scene managing, etc, you might wanna use one of them instead. They are harder to use though, you get good results much slower, and you need a certain math / gfx background. XNA is slightly higher level than OpenGL (Note though, that it doesn’t use it), being a somewhat “light” wrapper for DirectX, plus having quite a few other libraries.

Read full topic

item.title: Good 3D Engine
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Awesome, thanks for more help again Cheese_Police.
I’m tackling the RPG last on my list, but I wanted to get familiar with the engine before I went after it so this is perfect.

Read full topic

item.title: Good 3D Engine
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:5, topic:244582”]Well TBH if I were designing a game I’d probably do it in Java, but due to my Computing course at college they want me to use C#. (Not that we need to do 3d design), I’d just like to further my knowledge of C# in that direction.
So my question was that does Tao.OpenGL work with C#, and how good is it? Would you suggest XNA be a better choice?[/quote]
What you could do…Use Tao.OpenGL for your classes, then you can use JOGL if you want to use Java to make a game. That way you can carry over your knowledge of OpenGL. This could also apply for Python, or any other language with an low level OpenGL binding.

Read full topic

I’m making my own Source-like engine in C# and XNA.

item.title: Good 3D Engine
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Never used the C# bindings, but Ogre is a very nice engine. You can go as low level with it as you need to, while still being able to just manipulate it at a high level. It’s lovely.

Read full topic

item.title: Good 3D Engine
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:4, topic:244582”][quote author=davidude36 link=topic=320967.msg2539202#msg2539202 date=1226918462]
I’m interested in this too. So ogre3d would be a good way to start with 3d graphics in C#?
[/quote]
Depends what you want to do with 3D graphics. If you really want to learn 3d programming, you should try Tao.OpenGL or XNA. If you want to make a game and have no interest in understanding the low level workings of 3d graphics, then perhaps go with Ogre.[/quote]
Well TBH if I were designing a game I’d probably do it in Java, but due to my Computing course at college they want me to use C#. (Not that we need to do 3d design), I’d just like to further my knowledge of C# in that direction.
So my question was that does Tao.OpenGL work with C#, and how good is it? Would you suggest XNA be a better choice?

Read full topic

item.title: Good 3D Engine
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

davidude36:

I’m interested in this too. So ogre3d would be a good way to start with 3d graphics in C#?

Depends what you want to do with 3D graphics. If you really want to learn 3d programming, you should try Tao.OpenGL or XNA. If you want to make a game and have no interest in understanding the low level workings of 3d graphics, then perhaps go with Ogre.

Read full topic
